cracking-the-pm-interview.title: Cracking the PM Interview

product-sense.definition: The ability to identify user problems and design solutions that address real needs
evaluationCriteria: Can they identify the core user problem?
Do they understand user needs and use cases?
Can they design features that solve real problems?
Do they think about different user types and their specific needs?

structured-thinking.definition: The ability to break down complex problems into manageable components
evaluationCriteria: Do they ask clarifying questions before jumping to solutions?
Can they structure their approach systematically?
Do they identify users, use cases, and goals clearly?
Can they break down problems into smaller, manageable pieces?

customer-focus.definition: Understanding that products should be designed for users, not personal preferences
evaluationCriteria: Do they think about what users want vs. what they personally want?
Can they identify different user personas and their needs?
Do they consider use cases and user goals?
Are they realistic about tradeoffs and limitations?

business-acumen.definition: Understanding the business context and making decisions that drive value
evaluationCriteria: Do they consider business goals and metrics?
Can they balance user needs with business objectives?
Do they think about market size and opportunity?
Can they make data-driven decisions?

leadership-without-authority.definition: The ability to influence and lead teams without direct authority
evaluationCriteria: Do they show initiative and drive?
Can they influence others through vision and research?
Do they take ownership of outcomes?
Can they work collaboratively across teams?

product-design.name: Product Design Framework
steps: Ask questions to understand the problem
Provide a structure for your approach
Assess current solutions and weak spots
keyQuestions: Who are the users and customers?
What are the use cases and goals?
How well do current solutions address these needs?
What features would improve the weak spots?

case-analysis.name: Case Analysis Framework
steps: Show strong instincts and business judgment
keyQuestions: How can we break this down into smaller pieces?
What are the key business drivers?
What are the tradeoffs and limitations?

behavioral-assessment.name: Behavioral Assessment Framework
keyQuestions: Can you give me an example of when you led without authority?
Tell me about a time you solved a difficult problem
How do you work with engineers and designers?
What was your biggest impact in your last role?

characteristics: Asks clarifying questions before jumping to solutions
Shows structured thinking and clear methodology
Demonstrates deep user empathy and customer focus
Thinks about tradeoffs and limitations realistically
Can break down complex problems systematically
Can identify key problems and solutions
Jumps to solutions without understanding problem
Focuses on personal preferences over user needs

commonMistakes: Jumping to solutions without asking clarifying questions
Focusing on personal preferences instead of user needs
Not considering different user types and use cases
Not thinking about tradeoffs and limitations

product-sense: How would you validate this solution with users?
What metrics would you use to measure success?
How would you prioritize these features?
What are the potential risks or limitations?
strategy: How does this align with business goals?
How would you compete with existing solutions?
What would be your go-to-market strategy?
execution: How would you work with engineering to build this?
What would be your MVP approach?
How would you handle technical constraints?
What's your timeline and resource requirements?
